Title: How to prove limit of integral is $\frac{1}{n2^n}$?
Content:
I was wondering how to prove that $$\lim_{n\to \infty}\int_{1}^{n}\frac{1}{(x^{2}+1)^{n}}dx\sim \frac{1}{n\cdot 2^{n}}?.$$ This appears to be asymptotic to $\frac{1}{n2^{n}}$, but how to prove it?. I checked with larger and larger values of n, and it does get closer and closer to 
$$\frac{1}{n2^{n}}.$$ i.e 
$$\int_{1}^{10}\frac{1}{(x^{2}+1)^{10}}dx\approx .00009843725636$$
and 
$$\frac{1}{10\cdot 2^{10}}\approx .00009765625.$$ The larger $n$, the closer they get. I tried using parts to no avail. I also thought $$\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\binom{-n}{k}x^{2k}=\frac{1}{(1+x^{2})^{n}}$$ may be useful in some manner. Does anyone have a good idea as to how to prove this? Thanks
